title: Abstract: Unit 4 Lesson 3 - Community Connection and Participatory Sensing Campaign Design
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3, titled 'Community Connection,' focuses on guiding students to research and evaluate information from accredited sources to inform the design of their community-focused Participatory Sensing campaigns. The lesson emphasizes the critical skill of source verification using the SIFT method (Stop, Investigate the Source, Find Trusted Coverage, Trace claims). Students will identify a real-world community problem, choose a topic, and formulate a research question for their team-based campaigns, contrasting Participatory Sensing with traditional surveys. Key resources include 'Web Literacy for Student Fact-Checkers' and several 'Online Verification Skills' videos. The lesson culminates in students selecting a campaign topic and developing initial research questions, preparing them for the subsequent stages of campaign creation.

title: Unit 4 Lesson 3 Objective: Designing Community-Focused Participatory Sensing Campaigns
body: The primary objective of Unit 4 Lesson 3, 'Community Connection,' is for students to become proficient in researching and critically reviewing articles from accredited sources. This research will directly guide them in the design phase of their community-focused Participatory Sensing campaigns. By the end of the lesson, students should be able to identify reliable information to establish the context for real-world problems their campaigns will address, ensuring their projects are grounded in trustworthy data. This skill is crucial for creating impactful and data-driven solutions within their communities.

title: Key Materials for Source Verification and Campaign Development in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3 requires a range of materials to support students in designing their Participatory Sensing campaigns and verifying sources. Essential resources include the 'Web Literacy for Student Fact-Checkers' pressbook, and a series of 'Online Verification Skills' videos covering 'Investigate the Source,' 'Verifying Images and Videos,' and 'Find the Original Source.' Students will also use the 'Team Campaign Creation' handout (LMR_U4_L2). To aid in topic selection, the lesson provides example articles and data files on subjects like the 'Great Pacific Garbage Patch' (with 'US Landfills' data), 'California's drought' (with 'US Drought' data), 'homelessness in America' (with 'Annual Homeless Assessment Report' data), and the 'COVID-19 pandemic's impact on mental health' (with 'National Health Interview Survey' data).

title: Essential Concepts: Participatory Sensing for Real-World Community Problems in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: A core essential concept highlighted in Unit 4 Lesson 3 is that data collected through Participatory Sensing Campaigns will be utilized to create models that address and answer real-world problems relevant to the community. This underscores the practical application of data science in solving local challenges. To achieve this, students in Unit 4 Lesson 3 are tasked with researching accredited sources to define the context of these problems, ensuring their Participatory Sensing campaigns are built upon a solid foundation of reliable information and directly contribute to community well-being. The lesson emphasizes the importance of verifying information to avoid misinformation.

title: Initiating Participatory Sensing Campaign Design: Topic and Research Question Selection in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: In Unit 4 Lesson 3, students embark on the initial phase of designing their team-based Participatory Sensing campaigns. This critical step involves deciding on a specific topic and formulating a precise research question. To contextualize the real-world problem their campaign will address, students are required to review articles and select at least one accredited source. This process ensures that their campaigns are relevant and based on credible information. The 'Team Campaign Creation' handout (LMR_U4_L2) serves as a key tool to guide teams through this brainstorming and decision-making process.

title: The Importance of Source Reliability in Participatory Sensing Campaigns (Unit 4 Lesson 3)
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3, 'Community Connection,' places significant emphasis on the crucial need to check the reliability of sources. This step is paramount to ensure that students do not inadvertently spread misinformation or base their Participatory Sensing campaign research on untrustworthy or inaccurate information. The lesson highlights that a strong, credible foundation is necessary for creating effective and ethical community-focused campaigns. Students are therefore guided through methods and resources to critically evaluate the information they gather, directly impacting the integrity and success of their projects.

title: Introduction to the SIFT Method for Source Credibility in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3 introduces the SIFT method as an effective strategy for students to check the credibility and reliability of online sources. Adapted from 'Web Literacy for Student Fact-Checkers' by Michael A. Caulfield, SIFT stands for Stop, Investigate the Source, Find Trusted Coverage, and Trace claims, quotes, and media back to the original context. This method provides a structured approach to evaluate information critically, preventing the spread of misinformation and ensuring that the data and context for their community-focused Participatory Sensing campaigns are accurate and trustworthy.

title: SIFT Step 1: 'Stop' to Evaluate Sources in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: The first step of the SIFT method, taught in Unit 4 Lesson 3, is 'Stop.' This crucial initial action involves two key considerations. Firstly, students are prompted to ask themselves if they already know and trust the source of the information. The directive is clear: do not read or share content until the source's credibility is established. Secondly, if students find themselves getting lost in a 'click cycle' of numerous links and facts, they are instructed to STOP and refocus on their original research goal, preventing them from being sidetracked and ensuring efficient, targeted information gathering for their Participatory Sensing campaigns.

title: SIFT Step 2: 'Investigate the Source' for Reliability in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: In Unit 4 Lesson 3, the second step of the SIFT method, 'Investigate the Source,' guides students to proactively determine the origin and nature of information before fully engaging with it. This involves taking time to conduct a quick Google or Wikipedia search if the source is unfamiliar. The lesson provides a specific video resource, 'Online Verification Skills - Investigate the Source' (https://www.youtube.com/watch_popup?v=hB6qjIxKltA), to further assist students in developing the skills necessary to effectively investigate and understand the background and potential biases of a source. This ensures that information used for their Participatory Sensing campaigns is reliable.

title: SIFT Step 3: 'Find Trusted Coverage' and Verify Media in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: The 'Find Trusted Coverage' step, integral to Unit 4 Lesson 3's SIFT method, focuses on verifying the reliability of claims and media. Students are advised to perform a Google News search for relevant stories to see how other reputable outlets are reporting on the same topic. Additionally, utilizing known fact-checking sites such as snopes.com, factcheck.org, or politifact.com is recommended. For images within a source, students learn to conduct a reverse image search via Google to check their validity or discover if they have been used out of context. A helpful video, 'Online Verification Skills - Verifying Images and Videos' (https://www.youtube.com/watch_popup?v=7eKG9RuqUE4), is provided to guide this process, ensuring accurate data for Participatory Sensing campaigns.

title: SIFT Step 4: 'Trace Claims, Quotes, and Media' to Original Context in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: The final step of the SIFT method in Unit 4 Lesson 3 is 'Trace claims, quotes, and media back to the original context.' This step teaches students to recognize instances of re-reporting or commentary, often indicated by phrases like 'As reported by…' or 'According to…'. The goal is to go beyond secondary sources and locate the primary, original context of the information. This ensures that facts are not taken out of proportion or misrepresented. To support this skill, a dedicated video, 'Online Verification Skills - Find the Original Source' (https://www.youtube.com/watch_popup?v=tRZ-N3OvvUs), is included in the lesson's materials, enhancing students' ability to establish reliable foundations for their Participatory Sensing campaigns.

title: Distinguishing Participatory Sensing Campaigns from Surveys in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: During Unit 4 Lesson 3, students engage in a 'Pair-Share' discussion to differentiate when a Participatory Sensing campaign is more appropriate than a traditional survey. The key distinction lies in the nature of the research question: Participatory Sensing campaigns are best suited for questions that require observing variations across different times or locations. These campaigns often necessitate a 'trigger' to record observations at multiple points. Conversely, if a question needs to be answered only once, a survey typically serves as a more efficient method. This discussion helps students choose the most effective data collection strategy for their community-focused campaigns.

title: Transition to Team-Based Participatory Sensing Campaign Creation in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3 marks a significant transition in how students approach campaign development. Unlike Unit 3, where the entire class collaborated on a single campaign, in this lesson, each student team will independently create and implement their own Participatory Sensing campaign. These campaigns will address a community concern or interest identified by the team. To facilitate this, the 'Team Campaign Creation' handout (LMR_U4_L2) is distributed, providing a structured framework for teams to brainstorm topics, formulate research questions, and plan their unique community-focused projects, building on skills learned in Unit 4 Lesson 3 regarding source credibility.

title: Environmental Topics and Data for Participatory Sensing Campaigns in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: For students needing assistance in selecting a topic for their team Participatory Sensing campaigns in Unit 4 Lesson 3, several environmental issues are recommended. These include the 'Great Pacific Garbage Patch,' with an accompanying article from howstuffworks.com, supported by data from 'US Landfills' provided by the EPA (epa.gov/lmop/landfill-technical-data). This topic aligns with the theme of trash previously discussed in Unit 4 Lesson 1. Another option is 'California's drought,' with an NPR article on its persistence, complemented by historical 'US Drought' data from drought.gov. This topic connects to discussions from Unit 4 Lesson 2, providing a tangible real-world problem for student investigation.

title: Social and Health Topics and Data for Participatory Sensing Campaigns in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3 offers several social and health topics as potential areas for students to develop their team Participatory Sensing campaigns. One suggested topic is homelessness in America, accompanied by a USA Today article detailing its increase in 2023 due to the high cost of living, with supporting data from the 'Annual Homeless Assessment Report (AHAR)' available on huduser.gov. Another critical area is mental health, specifically the 'COVID-19 pandemic's impact' leading to a 25% increase in anxiety and depression worldwide, as reported by the WHO, with related data found in the 'National Health Interview Survey (NHIS)' from the CDC (cdc.gov/nchs/nhis/data-questionnaires-documentation.htm). These options provide relevant community concerns for students to explore.

title: Facilitating Initial Campaign Topic Selection in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: The latter part of Unit 4 Lesson 3 is dedicated to students actively engaging in the brainstorming and selection of topics for their team Participatory Sensing campaigns. Using the 'Team Campaign Creation' handout (LMR_U4_L2), teams find and review articles that will form the basis for their projects. The instructor circulates, facilitating these brainstorm sessions and offering guidance, particularly if teams struggle to find articles or choose a topic. The recommended articles and data files, covering environmental, social, and health issues, serve as valuable starting points, ensuring that students connect their campaigns to relevant community concerns and develop well-researched topics.

title: Unit 4 Lesson 3 Concluding Activities and Homework: Research Question Development
body: Towards the end of Unit 4 Lesson 3, student teams share their chosen Participatory Sensing campaign topics with the class. This brief share-out allows for peer awareness and potential feedback. For homework, students are tasked with formulating at least two possible research questions for their selected campaign topic. The expectation is that in the subsequent class period, teams will reach a consensus on their final research question, building upon the research and topic selection initiated in Unit 4 Lesson 3. This assignment ensures continued progress on their community-focused Participatory Sensing projects.

title: Redundancy Check: Core Objective and SIFT Method in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: Unit 4 Lesson 3, 'Community Connection,' clearly sets the objective for students to research accredited sources and utilize this information to design community-focused Participatory Sensing campaigns. A cornerstone of this process is the emphasis on source credibility, directly addressed by introducing and applying the SIFT method (Stop, Investigate the Source, Find Trusted Coverage, Trace claims). This ensures students develop robust data-driven campaigns, avoiding misinformation by critically evaluating the articles and data they select to define their real-world problems. The lesson's structure reinforces these core skills for effective campaign development.

title: Redundancy Check: Materials and Skills for Source Credibility in Unit 4 Lesson 3
body: In Unit 4 Lesson 3, the range of provided materials directly supports the critical skill of checking source credibility for Participatory Sensing campaigns. The 'Web Literacy for Student Fact-Checkers' pressbook and the 'Online Verification Skills' video series (Investigate the Source, Verifying Images and Videos, Find the Original Source) are integral to teaching the SIFT method. These resources equip students with the necessary tools to identify reliable information, ensuring that the contextual articles and data files they choose for their team campaigns, such as those on the Great Pacific Garbage Patch or homelessness, are accurate and suitable for addressing community issues.
